content.title: Venous Leg Ulcer
content.definition: Open skin defect of the lower leg resulting from chronic venous insufficiency and sustained venous hypertension, representing the most common type of leg ulcer (70-80% of all leg ulcers). Typically located in the gaiter zone (medial malleolus area) with characteristic shallow, irregular margins and surrounding skin changes.

key_concepts.description: Venous hypertension from reflux/obstruction → capillary distension → fibrin cuff formation → leukocyte trapping → chronic inflammation → tissue hypoxia → ulceration
Gaiter zone (lower third of leg, especially medial malleolus area); lateral malleolus less common; rarely above mid-calf. Location is a key differentiator from arterial ulcers
Shallow, irregular borders; pink granulation tissue base (if healthy); yellow slough or fibrinous exudate; large size often; relatively painless or mild aching (less pain than arterial ulcers)
Lipodermatosclerosis (hardened, shiny, brown skin); hemosiderin staining (brown pigmentation); eczema; atrophie blanche (white atrophic patches); varicose veins; edema
Usually less painful than arterial ulcers; aching pain that worsens with standing/dependency and improves with elevation (opposite of arterial rest pain)

C6 = active venous ulcer; C5 = healed venous ulcer. E (etiology): Ep = primary, Es = secondary (post-thrombotic). A (anatomy): superficial, deep, perforator. P (pathophysiology): reflux, obstruction, both
Cornerstone of treatment; multi-layer compression bandaging or stockings provide 30-40 mmHg; contraindicated if ABI <0.5 (significant arterial disease). Reduces healing time by 50%
Essential before compression to rule out significant arterial disease; ABI >0.8 = safe for full compression; 0.5-0.8 = modified/reduced compression; <0.5 = compression contraindicated
Moist wound healing principles; debride slough/necrotic tissue; appropriate dressings based on exudate (foams for heavy, hydrocolloids for moderate); infection control if colonized
Superficial venous ablation (if reflux present) accelerates healing and reduces recurrence; perforator ablation; skin grafting for large ulcers; iliac vein stenting for obstruction
High recurrence rate (30-70% at 1 year without maintenance compression); lifelong compression stockings essential; venous intervention reduces but doesn't eliminate recurrence

differential_diagnosis: Malignancy (squamous cell in chronic ulcer - Marjolin ulcer)
content.statement: Venous Leg Ulcer is a fundamental concept in Health-Sciences Medicine Surgery Vascular Pathology Venous-Ulcer that provides essential knowledge for understanding related topics and clinical/practical applications.

explanation.technical_details: Technical details involve specific mechanisms, measurements, and evidence-based applications of Venous Leg Ulcer.

learning_objectives: Identify characteristic features of venous ulcers (location, appearance, skin changes)
Distinguish from arterial ulcers using clinical features and ABI
Understand the central role of compression therapy in treatment
Recognize the importance of lifelong compression for recurrence prevention
clinical_pearls: Medial malleolus (gaiter zone) = venous until proven otherwise
Pain improved by elevation = venous; worsened by elevation = arterial
Always check ABI before compression - contraindicated if <0.5
Hemosiderin staining and lipodermatosclerosis = chronic venous disease
30-70% recurrence at 1 year without maintenance compression
Marjolin ulcer: malignant transformation in chronic non-healing ulcer - biopsy if suspicious
common_mistakes: Applying compression without checking ABI (can cause gangrene in arterial disease)
Stopping compression after ulcer heals (high recurrence)
Missing Marjolin ulcer (SCC in chronic ulcer) - always biopsy non-healing ulcers
Over-treating with antibiotics (most ulcers are colonized, not infected)
